Cutting Diet:

Calories: TDEE

Adjust calories as needed based on your goals / results.

>>69652584
This is going to be hard to explain, but time under tension is the true objective when working with weights. Rocking into a rep reduces that time and it reduces the sections of the rep that you are actually putting work into. The elbow is moving about 90 degrees when curling, but if you cheat for the first 30 degrees then you are only getting benefit for the remaining ~60 degrees. This could make other motions that do not permit the same cheating to suffer.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Don’t start eating more just yet, you’ll have a higher chance of getting it wrong and just gaining the wrong kind of weight (fat)

Firstly you want to increase your workout intensity. Train until you fail and then push just a little further, you’ll surprise yourself with how easy you are probably going on yourself - this way you can track how your body responds and at the very least shed some fat and start to get some definition. Once you’ve done that and you know you can make your body respond then look at you macros and getting protein and fats etc

Increase how often you workout if that’s possible with your schedule, otherwise a bro split 5 days a week is completely fine as long as you adhere to keeping the intensity up, you wanna fuck your muscles up every session

It takes time but you will slowly notice the changes

I made the mistake of picking a program and doing the reps an sets and eating the calories and I just got fat

If you’re just starting out learn out to exercise til failure first and then learn how to eat

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Return of the ducks edition

>Who is /fat/ for?
For fatties who are working towards a better physique through meaningful hard-work, strategy, and dedication. This is not QTDDTOT, stick to questions on fat loss. Post height and weight when asking for advice.
Join our Fatty Contest: https://www.fattycontest.com/

>What do I do first?
1. Read https://physiqonomics.com/fat-loss/
2. Calculate your Body Fat Percentage: https://fitness.bizcalcs.com/Calculator.asp?Calc=Body-Fat-Navy
3. Calculate your TDEE: https://www.sailrabbit.com/bmr/
Remember to use bodyfat% and use Katch-McArdle Formula with sedentary settings or your TDEE will be too high.
4. Plan your weight loss: https://www.losertown.org/eats/cal.php
5. Track your nutrition with MyFitnessPal (better for packaged food), Cronometer (better for generic food/macros) or LoseIt (great for both).

>Now what?
Count calories, all of them.
Eat about 500-1000 less calories than your TDEE.
Buy scales, be accurate.
Learn to cook. Try to stick to lean protein and green vegetables.
Eat a lot of protein. 0.72g per lb of goal lean body mass.
Doing cardio, even just walking, will improve your health. There is no such thing as a healthy fat heart, but you can offset the risks.
Lifting weights will keep and gain muscle mass and burn fat much quicker. No lifting results in the body burning away muscle AND fat.
Drink more water.
Read the /fit/ sticky: https://liamrosen.com/fitness.html

>DON'T
Eat refined sugars, they're terrible for you regardless of calories.
Eat processed foods.
Drink your calories (alcohol, soda, starbucks).
Freak out over a weight loss stall. Plateaus can last up to three weeks.
"Reward" yourself. Cheat days cheat only yourself.

>Other resources:
Loose skin, gyno & stretch marks: https://weight-loss-side-effects.netlify.app/
Reddit wiki: https://www.reddit.com/r/loseit/wiki/faq

>>69657723
Try it, but the people giving you shit are the ones who already tried it, and got the same results. Keto’s biggest issue is sustainability. You will want to have a normal diet eventually, so when you do you will rebound and gain all the weight back because you didn’t fix the core issues that made you fat to begin with. you need to learn portion control, calorie counting, and a bonus of learning how to cook because makes it easier. You can have a normal diet, and even have treats, but you just need to do it responsibly and learn a new way to go about food. Easier said that done, but once you do you will succeed.

A good author will give you juuust enough detail to be able to create your own mental image of the character or environments, but never enough to force an image.

It's straight up wrong. Depending on what time you workout you want to fast (if you workout very early in the morning), otherwise you'll want carbs before and after your workout. Protein is a little more flexible, you can definitely skip it pre-workout but it won't hurt eating before (as long as digestion doesn't affect your workout).

>>69649594
antagonist forces between resistance and structure
wrists along straight arms with grip will make a circle along shoulder rotation maintaining wrist and arm angle
second angel correct of the elbows can turn the arm into a piston
this is the bench press
a third angle of rotation is the wrist itself, notice on yourself how short the angle of rotation is
therefore the width of grip will be depending on the angle of rotation of the wrist, in regards to bench press.
rotate the wrist away from the body you can create a closer grip, notice the correction in the elbow as the piston is now bend outwards, the weight on the bone is now along one side and pulling on the joint of the wrist.
rotate your wrist towards your body, the correction is the opposite.
She begins with her wrists over rotated, so on the way down the body handles it because it is slowing the bar force, it is the reverse motion where the maximum amount of force is along the one side of the bone.
In short, never grip so wide, keep the variation of grip within reason of the wrist.
Bones are a lot stronger along them than against them.

I'll bite and answer your question :
No that's not how it works.
Lemme explain :
- You have a scale. You turn it on. It shows "zero".
- You take a bowl or other receptacles and place it on the scale, while it's empty.
- The scale shows the weight of the bowl, bowl weighs let's say 50 grams.
- Then you pressa special button called "TARE".
That button's job is to reset the scale's measure back to zero. Meaning if you took the bowl off the scale after that, the scale would show "-50 grams".
So after you use TARE to reset the weight to zero, you can just add the sugar or other ingredient to measure it and the scale has alreadyaccountedfor the bowl's weight by restting to zero.

That's how scales work. Turn on scale, but bowl, on it, use TARE button, andthen add whaever you want ot measure to the bowl.

My headcanon is that 531 isn't really a powerlifting program, it is an all around fitness program that in its latest iterations puts a lot of emphasis on conditioning. You'll find forums outside 4chan dedicated to this program, and they all preach the value of the conditioning as a supplement and catalyst to the strength gains. I've had great experiences with it myself during cutting, and I'm taking a lot of inspo from it in my own programming.

>>69657784
Saw this from Justin Lascek's TM book.

>Weighted pull-ups can be progressed with three sets of five reps until they stall, after which various rep schemes can be utilized to garner progress. Some examples include three to five sets of three reps with heavier weight, sets of doubles, or rotating a different rep max each week (8RM, 5RM, 3RM, and rotate). If heavy doubles, triples, or repetition maxes are used, the trainee can always drop to either a lighter percentage or body weight for a set of maximal reps. Personally, I had a lot of success when doing a few sets at a heavier weight, then at 50 pounds, then as many reps as I could do at 25 pounds, then as many as I could do at body weight (at the end of a session, I PR’d with 21 reps at a body weight of 212)

Also I personally used to use this method also from his TM Part 1 book:
>A progression of three sets of five will work for these exercises, but once the weight is over thirty pounds, a trainee can get creative. One method is to use three sets of five (as heavy as possible with full range of motion), then half the weight and go for max reps, and then go for max reps with just body weight. Another method is to warm-up to a heavy triple, back off for a couple sets of five, then go for reps with 25 pounds, and then go for reps with body weight.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>69655963
Daily is best, but daily meditation should be kept short at max 10 minutes.

On top of that should be weekly meditation that gradually grows longer and longer. For both would recommend starting at one minute, and slowly going longer and longer until you hit 10 minutes for daily. Then you can work on making weekly longer and longer.

For my weekly meditation I'm at nearly 2 hours now. It really helps get rid of all the bullshit that builds up during the work week.

>>69661024
>What? The whole point of the rdl is that it lets you cut rom off the bottom of the sldl. Why would you do it on a deficit?
The difference between a SLDL and a RDL is that a SLDL is deadstop while a RDL is not (making the SLDL more specific to the deadlift due to the fact that you have to break the weight off the floor on every rep on both lifts while you don't have to on a RDL). The reason why that tiny bit of ROM is cut off is so that the plates don't touch the floor. I do RDLs with an arched back, knees behind ankles, a wide grip, and the biggest deficit I can use without crushing my toes because I need the extra range of motion to maximally stretch my hamstrings. If I did RDLs to mid-shin I would get a much poorer hamstring stimulus as I wouldn't get a full stretch on them, so I would be ego-lifting.

My mum died in November. She was diagnosed with cancer and given a few months to live. We held a small birthday party for her in her hospital room, but in the evening she started to deteriorate and was gone about a day and half later.

I was already not in a great place before that, but I haven't been doing well since. And I'm the kind of person who finds it hard to reach out and talk to people. Dying sucks, bros. I don't mean being dead, but the process of dying. It's not like in the movies.

January is the worst time of year anyway (Northern Europe), but I'm finding it hard to see the metaphorical light. It's a struggle at the minute to put any effort into things that will bear fruit in what feels like the intangible future. Think I should get out and socialise more, but it's not coming easy atm.

I just wanted to hear some words from anyone who's lost someone close, and how it feels 12, 24 months down the line.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69657430
Do you need to believe all of it be to be Christian? Christianity itself is very broad, and (to me) it's nested in the larger broad group of world spiritual systems. There are some underlying principles that arw rteu across all of them, but you should be Christian if you think they find their fullest and most accurate expression in Christianity. But if you don't, it's okay, Christianity and Atheism aren't the only two options.

For me, I was an atheist from a young age even though I went to Christian schools, but I always had a connection to what I'd now call the transcendant. Around my mid teens, I had a crisis of meaning and started to read more about faith systems that I was drawn to, mostly Buddhism, but also some syncretic teachings. It was by studying Eastern religions that I began to understand Christianity for the first time and why people are Christian. I'd rejected what was basically a child understanding of religion and was becoming aware of a deeper level of understanding.

I don't think 'faith' necessarily means 'blind faith'. It's a stable conviction, coking from a mixture of reasoning, experience, and inspiration. It's really a form of trust. Trust takes time to build, but it's one of the most important and emotionally sustaining elements in our life. A spiritual practice is a process. Don't start with conclusions, have a certain amount of initial trust to begin the path and accept the journey won't be easy but will be rewarding.

2. Don't be a roll-over simp
You keep your emotions in check. Sure you can acknowledge and compliment her, it's part of the process of showing subtle, respectful interest. But your words are measured, you don't overtly spill out your emotions. A flat, cold but respectful affect is what you need. Bite your tongue before you think about spurting out some overtly nice comment. Measure yourself.
Secondly, you don't give her too easy a time. The reason she instinctively pulls back with you is because she is insecure, and because men with stature and respect often give her a hard time. They keep her accountable, they value her but are strict and severe enough to not fall head over heels for her. So you must know when to pick battles with her. If she is clearly stepping out on a professional level, taking an odd stance etc. Be the one to remind her respectfully. Don't be afraid to drop the hammer, in a strict but affectionate way. This also will send her reeling. If you pipe up with something like ''While your idea is valued, Sandra...I do not think, as (boss) said that this is the right time to be thinking about expansion etc''. Like come in with a little jab, but package it nicely.
Then sometimes later...you let her cool down etc. She will take it personally 100%, so give her some time to let off the steam. You come back and in passing and say ''I liked (your idea.) I just don't think it's time yet. But you should consider presenting it in a more strategic manner. Make a report. You are good at those.'' And then you leave.
She will fucking never get over you. How can you be so sweet, yet so harsh at times. You obviously care, she will think. You respect her. But you are your own man. You are not afraid to hold her accountable/criticize her in a respectful manner.
Beautiful women look for men with spine but also a man who subtly tells them ''I know you can do better, i am not impressed'' but also ''you could be the one that impresses me if you just try''.

Bloodflow bloodflow bloodflow
If you have an elliptical/stationary bike in your gym, go backwards on it and slowly go faster/increase resistance at whatever rate you can go at without your knee hurting. Do this for 5-10 minutes until you have a sickening quad pump. After doing this for a few days (weeks in some cases) your knees should feel fine. Also consider doing ATG squats after this if you can without pain (as you should find that you can do more stuff without hurting directly after doing that), but don't bother if it still hurts

I have back of knee pain and the only thing that works is being active. I think my calf muscle or the related tendons are tight. I went to a sports med doctor some five or so years ago and he said without doing a biopsy that the fascia around my muscles is a bit too tight -- so basically just doing lots of activity will help loosen it but it is what it is.

Every time I stop working out the pain comes back, particularly in the mornings after sleep.

Good luck anon, get fit and the pain goes away

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Is your pain increasing because you add weight ? Ie, can you do a body squat whit no pain ?
If so, it might be a tendonitis. You don't need to stop training, but you need for the inflammation to get lower.
For that, train your legs with lighter weights and higher reps, but make sure the pain never increases workout after workouts
Let's say you have a 5/10 pain, just make sure it doesn't increase. If done correctly, your pain will lower itself over time, aka *months*.
Also, rest, ice.
>Source : my rehab plan and my sport therapist.

Nietzsche is a great philosopher, but hard to understand directly. I read Niezstche back in high school, but also a companion book by Walter Kauffman "Nietzsche: Philosopher, Psychologist, Antichrist" that explains some of the eccentricities in his writing, and interprets some of the more difficult ideas for you.
I'm 25 now and Nietzsche's teachings have not let me down, or more like he was way more correct about the world than I ever could have imagined while in high school. His description of the ubermensch was literally a bunch of physically dominant chads with supreme self control and a love for life. Nietzsche was himself a great lover of exercise, he always lauded the joy of hiking in the mountains. I'm sure he would have taken to strength training if he had the exposure and his health wasn't so poor.

>Advice for new runners
- Build up speed and mileage SLOOOOWLY (start with 15 minutes, increase time/mileage by 10% per week)

I started boxing about 5 months ago, definitely recommend it to anyone looking to get a practical martial art under there belt and also seriously raise their fitness level. It's seriously tough when you start, not just cause of the amount of cardio necessary to perform well but also cause you realise how skilled others are and how much you have to learn. My advice to anyone looking to pick it up is find a decent gym/club and make sure you're going at least 2-3 times a week. Make sure to ask questions and engage with your coach that'll help out a lot.

I mean in all honesty you'll never get hit that hard in sparring, even heavy sparing. Between the gloves and the headgear all blows are fairly cushioned. You wont be sparing till you have a decent knowledge of movement and defence so unless you're terrible or just not concentrating you shouldn't be getting battered around the place. If you wanna fight in matches or even go semi-pro/pro then yeah there's a higher risk of long term brain injury but honestly lad if you're just looking to take it up as a hobby and a way to learn to fight it's unlikely you're brain is in any danger.

>>69645595
Depends on the gym. Headgear only helps prevents superficial damage like cuts. It does very little to mitigate the concussive force. Studies have been done that show that in a lot of cases headgear can be worse due to limited field of vision and larger target/more leverages to hit. Plus people naturally assume its okay to go harder because they see headgear. Same with gloves, while there is a big difference between 16 oz and 8 or 10 oz gloves, you can still get pretty messed up if you take too many hard shots to the head, even in the 16oz ones. But otherwise yeah everything you said is on point.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Yes. I've been boxing for 6 months or so. Have two buddies that are amateur fighters training me. Thus far, my observations:
- Cardio is great. I stopped running to train boxing in addition to lifting, got back into running for a halfathon and I feel fine running 5+ miles despite not running in months.
- Skill level is way higher in terms of fighting ability. I would absolutely obliterate myself from 6 months ago.
- Boxing is the ultimate pugalistic art. Boxing is very technical and focused. I think Muay Thai or general MMA training will make a better warrior, but nobody is EVER beating a boxer just throwing hands.
- Boxing training can be done anywhere. I have a double end bag and heavy bag, but I feel that shadow boxing, jumping rope, and just practicing footwork are all just as useful and can be done anywhere.

I'm probably going to switch to BJJ soon because I'm nearing my boxing limit without actually sparring every session. I train 3-4 times per week boxing (1-2 of which includes sparring or pad work), 2-3 times per week lifting.

I treat it like I treat lifting during my running race preps. Transition to a full body lifting routine of core compound exercises. Keep in mind my boxing routine is not always "full throttle". I have 2 days where I train with my buddies that are new techniques, pads, sparring, etc. then two days solo that are nearly rest days (15min of reflex ball, jumping rope, footwork), 5 rounds of shadowboxing 5 rounds of heavy bag.

I've lost muscle mass but that's because I've been lifting for 10 year at this point and eating 4000cals daily is very taxing on me mentally now. I am 6'1" 190lbs and burn cals like a fire.

The skill and enjoyment of boxing has been worth the minor loss of gainz.

Going to go ahead and say that this anon is correct. Anyone that trains in a boxing gym will probably be better than the vast majority of the people out there in terms of fighting potential. What I do recommend for people who are like me but didn't know, is that especially in America, 80% of the gyms out there are pure memes that will only teach you boxing as a sport, not as a fighting style meant to cause physical harm to your opponent, because real life is situated in war, life and death and not sports. I recommend to train with bare hands, make sure you train regularly for strength, and to build your muscles so you arms, forearms, shoulders, hips are all to notch. Doing cardio is also an essential aspect of fighting.

The next secret to fighting, especially someone who wants to cause you harm is INTENSITY. If you're not intense while maintaining form, you risk being taken out. Another suggestion to anyone's repertoire is to buy a handgun and either learn or pay someone to properly teach you the mechanics of how it is used.

Last point and one that barely anyone talks about is mental. Regular people often don't want to harm others and only do so when pushed into a corner, learn to lose that mentality and actively focus on hurting your opponent, there is no such thing as "honor" when life or death is at hand, you either win or lose. Anything that can be used to your advantage use it, effectively, aggressively and without second thought.

>Digestive enzymes
Bromelain has a functional pH range of 4-8. Papain has an optimal range of 5.8-7, and denatures at pH 5, your stomach acid is at pH 1.5 to 3.5. So it does not really work even if you eat it at the same time with your food. The way these are usually used is by chucking them onto meat for some time before you prepare it (tenderizing meat).

Yes Bifidobacterium and L. acidophilus are probiotics and one can argue if it does help or not. But beside that, you get the same bacteria from good fermented food. So you could just go for that instead of some magic powder.

>>69662380
do you have a coach? it's just one of those things where coaching *is* the cheat code, like if those guys are 60-70 they're probably just 1200-1500 and I feel like any young and fit person with enough coaching should break that if they can dedicate enough time to it (I'm probably biased because I know a guy who started in his 20s after quitting futsal and is actually 2200)

if not, the youtube channels I recommend are basically pingskills, tomorrow table tennis (his video on learning Fan Zhendong's reverse pendulum serve is insanely good and that serve is an easy ace against beginners if you can perfect it, the mechanics of it are just superior imo) and road to pro on youtube, and timo boll has a book that's available on libgen. do not listen to emratthich, he spouts orientalist woo and apparently just steals Chinese internet videos and gives his own loaded commentary

I'm assuming you your own non premade racket yet (decent equipment does wonders) but also do NOT take the tenergy meme. imo you should really be 1800 before even trying fast tensors or ALC blades, any cheap yinhe setup on aliexpress with palio ak47 is fine (that's like, $30? for my friend who started last year I just told him to get something from Gambler/Zeropong that cost him about $16 and he loves that shit). like I personally use a nittaku violin and I hate tenergy or rubbers as fast as it lol, most people just have very low spin sensitivity or muscle memory unless they develop it and in a game that's 90% unenforced errors you're better off going slow and steady

btw no chinese rubbers like hurricanes until you get a coach or make an older friend whose willing to drill with you either

>>69657910
Adult acne comes down to a few things, imo...
Diet
Hygiene
Stress

How clean is your diet? Are you eating lots of refined carbs and sugars, or keeping your carbs clean? Avoid lots of refined carbs like in store-bought bread, pasta, junk-food etc., and don't shy away from natural carb sources like those in fruit and milk. Eliminate junk-food entirely - no chips, no candy, no soda; limit alcohol if you drink often. No room for questions... got it?

How's your hygiene routine?
Are you showering too much, and always with hot water? You are stripping away the natural oils and your sebaceous glands are working hard to replace them. Replacing the oils with a moisturizer immediately after a hot shower, especially on your face, is crucial, as you'll avoid overworking your sebaceous glands - I believe overworked sebaceous glands get inflamed easily.
Are you not showering or washing your face enough?
Are you using quality (natural) soap and not overdoing it, or are you overdoing it with a harsh scented lab-grade bodywash? Are you touching your face?
I don't shower daily, but when I do I hit the main areas (pits, groin & ass, & feet) with an unscented, quality bar-soap; and I wash my face twice a day with cold water and a gentle facial cleanser then moisturize after, and my skin is super clear.

How stressed are you? Are you sleeping enough? When I'm stressed, I find myself touching my face; and when I'm not sleeping enough I get stressed out easily. I usually only get the random pimple every now and again because of the implications of stress.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
short answer: it's extremely complicated and involves 10+ different factors which can be contributing to it. if you go from the premise that acne is an inflammatory chronic illness (which it is), you can get a good framework to test things from.

things to consider.
1. cutting out ALL dairy and simple sugars, including whey
2. hygiene of clothing/bedding
3. codemogenicity of skincare products. what do you put on your face?
4. contact irritation/allergy testing
5. levels of stress and sleep
6. anabolic boosting supplement use (even creatine)
7. shaving routines - big cause of irritation
8. sunlight exposure
9. are you taking any medications currently? these can drastically affect skin conditions. certain supplements can cause chronic acne (B complex is a good but lesser known example).
10. smoking tobacco/weed (known to inflame skin kerotins)
11. rest of diet. evaluate simple carbs and sugars especially. this can and will include things like fruit, juices, white breads, etc.
12. NOW you can consider medication. isotretinoin unfortunately has extreme side effects and is directly linked to cataracts and eye problems later in life. wikipedia actually has a very good treatment matrix for acne depending on severity. generally you'll need 3-4 medications and multiple supplements AFTER you get the rest of everything else listed in order and eliminate inflammation and irritation. BP, azelaic acid, tretinoins, topical retinoids/antibiotics, salyclic acid, niacinamide are the usual first-line treatments. oral NSAIDs and supplementation with high dose zinc + normal reigments of omega 3, C, D3, melatonin and high dose B3 can help as well. alternative options include dermarolling and intensive daily red light treatment, those should be considered as well.

unfortunately acne is a chronic disease and ages 9-28 for men is considered "adolescent" skin which is prone to inflammation (kek). if you are under 30 understand acne is normal. ironically it actually gets worse for women

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69639045
Your calories seem a little low but YMMV - just make sure that if you're not gaining weight/strength you up your calories. Not anon from other thread but here's the problem with recomp - its subtle and slow. It is possible to do but its also possible that you try to recomp for 6 months and because you're screwing something up you end up doing fuck all for those 6 months. If you focus on distinct bulk/cut phases the changes you see will be bigger, occur faster and its easier to diagnose if something is going wrong. This comes at the cost of partially working against yourself (if you CAN get more muscular and less fat at the same time that would be awesome! but it requires being a) less experienced and b) getting pretty much everything right, which is not something someone who is less experienced is going to be good at)

>>69639787
The first phase is quite aggressive - not sure the context of the video but it might be warranted depending on the goal. I would always state that quick loss results in quick gains back - if you want the weight to come off and stay off you largely have to lose it slowly in a sustainable process you could imagine yourself continuing basically forever (if you can't its likely you'll just rebound when you stop the process)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>work out infrequently
>get doms
>enjoy doms
do I need to eat a lot of protein all through the doms or only the workout day? are my muscles still repairing in doms or is it something else?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69650806
Its advisable to keep your protein intake stable (at the usual level of 1g/lb of body weight) and spread out into 4-5 meals on both workout and rest days. That's the theoretical optimum but it doesn't make a huge difference if you only have 3 meals, just makes it easier to eat as much protein as you need.

DOMs are a side effect of muscle fibre disruption/damage not the repair process itself, but obviously you don't get repair without damage (unless you don't eat!) so we use it as a proxy. Your muscles will be repairing themselves both with and without DOMs being present, don't worry about timing protein intake around DOMs or even workouts, timing has a very minor impact quantity is more important.

Estimated calories burned from literally any device is a ballpark guess at best and are notoriously generous with the numbers they provide.
>3 mph at a fairly steep incline
anon...that's not burning 250 calories every 15 minutes. At best walking 3mph for an hour will burn around 220-240 calories, but that's walking continuously for an hour. With an incline it might increase it to 350-400 per hour, but a quarter of that is likely 100 calories at best. Cardio is a great way to squeeze some extra calories out but you can't out-exercise bad habits. Weight loss is 50% reduction in eating, 45% waiting, and 5% exercise.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: So I've heard that you can't do the same program over and over and that you need to constantly change them, how much truth is there to it? For strength gains, muscle growth gains, anything. Can I really not do let's say the same training programme for 8-12 weeks which switches up every 3 weeks or so and whenever I find an exercise too easy go up by 5lbs or more depending on how easy it feels and when the programme comes to it's 8th or 12th week, begin it once again?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69659941
Eventually your body adapts but if it ain't broke don't fix it. Changing things before they get stale and stop working is purposeless. Also when it comes to programming, the body gets more complex and resistant to changing the more it changes. Novice Linear Progression can work for quite some time, but eventually it stops working, for two reasons.
1. Not enough stimulus to grow/get stronger.
2. You've now become so strong that your body is literally unable to recover in time between sessions so you start to backslide due to muscular and/or CNS fatigue.
This stress, recovery, and adaptation cycle only gets longer and longer.

Drugs and therapy together definitely have a synergistic effect.
I probably didn't have PTSD but I was wrecked with severe anxiety, so you'll have to use your own judgement on how applicable this is to you.

>propanolol
Blunts physical symptoms of anxiety like shaking and elevated heart rate. Very effective at stopping a negative cycle of anxiety which grows into a panic attack. It's basically as safe as drugs come as long as your don't freak out and take 20 pills so it's probably the place to start.
>fluvoxamine
An SSRI which severely reduced my negative obsessive, intrusive thoughts and repeated ruminations and catastrophizing. I still get autistically obsessed with things I like. The only side effect I had was a small increase in hunger. So over all it was side effect free but I know that isn't the case for everyone. SSRIs can have bad side effects.
Doctors hand them out like candy because they think they are low risk, but I think they over-weight addiction in their risk assessment.
>Vorinostat
This one is a real game changer. You MUST work with a therapist for is one. It's a strange one, it blunts fear and improves your ability to learn. So taken in a controlled way through planned exposure therapy you can completely change your outlook. uuh, it's not healthy. Taken 400mg ED is a chemotherapy dose. We are looking for 150mg once per week.

My mom is both narcissistic and incompetent. My brother died in his mid-20s after having been isolated in the family basement like the literal stereotype since he dropped out of high school in grade 8. I can remember her telling me that my concern over his life was bizarre. She literally didn't understand that a family member would care that another family member was dying. The last 6 months of his life were spent vomiting almost continuously and being diagnosed with liver problems. He got taken to the hospital a few times the week before he died but he always checked himself out with Mom's blessing. Once when they were taking the idea of one of the nurses remarked that they could not believe he was being discharged. 2 days before he died I had dinner with mom. She told me the story of how that morning he'd woken her up screaming from the basement about how he was in horrible pain in his back. She told this like in the same manner as someone talking about the weather. When I found this out my jaw dropped and we left our dinner and went home and I finally managed to get a nurse on the telephone to convince him to go to the hospital. He was there for a few hours then checked out. Two days later I get a phone call from my mom telling me that he's died. Then she has months upon months of grief and everyone was so concerned about her as though she hadn't brought this upon her son. It's also very difficult to talk about with people who had normal parents because it's normal to fight with your parents to some degree and to think they didn't do everything right because no one does everything right. But some people do far less wrong and I really like people from competent families.

>>69661294
The reason why I say this is a powerlifting phenomenon is because there is truth to the idea that hip hinging will allow greater maximal loads compared with knee hinge, just because of how much more muscle we have around the hip.
It's for this reason that powerlifters prefer low bar squatting, because for them the knee hinge is essentially a limiting factor.
So powerlifters who get rid of knee hinge may see improved numbers, but not everybody is a powerlifter, so why do they try to push their sport specific strategy onto the average lifter?

There's a world of difference in between those two times though.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69651787
- avoid chronic stress, cortisol ages you badly
- don't get addicted to drugs, cigarettes, alcohol, meth and heroin are particularly bad. Weed, psychedelics and low-dose stimulants are ok in moderation
- eat healthy unprocessed foods. lower calorie diets seem to be better for longevity, and bulk/cut cycles put a lot of unneeded stress on the body. Staying 12-15% BF year round is best for longevity.
- avoid nutrient defficiencies, most common ones are magnesium, omega-3 and Vit D. Put all your food for a week into cronometer and see what's missing.
- 8 hours quality sleep per night. Missing sleep is one of the fastest ways to age, since your body can't repair itself.
- fasting triggers autophagy where the body can remove dead and damaged cells, essentially reversing aging at the cellular level. You need to fast at least 24 hours to start autophagy. I usually fast for one full day per month, and extend it to two days if I feel good.
- don't tan/sunburn and generally avoid excess sun exposure. Some (20 mins/day for white people) to get natural vitamin D is fine, but beyond that use sunscreen or cover your skin.
- excercise helps prevent aging, but excessive endurance cardio (think marathon runners) puts too much stress on the body and ages you. Strength training and HIIT cardio is best.
- Don't be lonely. Having a large amount of friends you see in person, and/or a healthy relationship massively lowers stress and reduces aging. If you're a hopeless sperg you can make friends at board game meetups, anime conventions and shit, or you can go out to a concert/festival and take MDMA to force to social pathways in your brain to activate.
- reduce oxidative stress on the body. NAC is a powerful antioxidant that's easily available. antiinflamatories like aspirin or CBD work to lower this as well (ibuprofen and paracetamol lower test and are generally toxic, aspirin and CBD are much healthier).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Hello again, I'm a little confused by the 3x8-12 over 3x10 statement. I'm reading it as a range of 8 to 12 reps, but that's just a two rep difference from 3x10 isnt it? How's that make a difference?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69654370
The difference is that you can go to failure (or close to it) on the earlier sets on a 3x8-12 because you can just slash reps on the later sets, while on a 3x10 you're forced to hold back on the first 2 sets so you still have the strength to get 10 reps on the last set.

For example, on a 3x10 you might get 10 reps with 3 RIR, then 10 with 2, then 10 with 1. On a 3x8-12 you might get 11 with 1 RIR, then 10 with 1 RIR, then 9 with 0 RIR. (Obv numbers are just examples but you get the idea).

Static reps are fine if the sets are very low because the sandbagging problem isn't so bad, for example if you do just 1 set there is no sandbagging because you can go to failure and have no problems because there aren't any sets afterward that you need to get the same reps on. Meanwhile a 10x10 for example is terrible because you would need to be like 7 reps away from failure on the first set to make it all the way to the tenth set without adjusting the weight, meaning that the earlier sets aren't stimulative at all and are junk volume.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69654536
>Can you explain why? I usually go down until I can feel a stretch.
Because typically over time as you do RDLs to your maximum hamstring flexibility, your hamstring flexibility naturally improves to the point where you have to go deeper to get a maximum stretch. Most people however still do the same ROM every time, only ever getting a mild hamstring stretch when they could be getting a better one for both better muscle gains and flexibility gains. In about a year I went from going to mid shin with a normal grip to going all the way down to my toes with a wide grip with even better technique (back arched, knees behind ankles, slow eccentric, pause).
>What are seated mornings and what does "rdls to deadlifts" mean?
Seated good mornings are just good mornings performed sitting on a bench. RDLs have high carryover to the hip extension part of the deadlift (which is most of the lift) while seated good mornings carry over to the hip extension part of the squat (which is only half of the lift as knee extension is also very important, so the RDL will inherently have more carryover but they're still similar in regards to hip extension).
>Hybrid?
Between a normal curl and a reverse curl
>How?
Any quad isolation (leg extensions, sissy squats). Some ab/hip flexor movements with straight legs also use it.

EG on squats if I do a 4x6-12 and I hit 12, 11, 10, 10 I would go up in weight and maybe I would get 9, 8, 7, 7 on my next session with the new weight for example. That being said, sometimes I may retake the weight a few times if I felt like the set of 12 was too sloppy just so I have an opportunity to clean up my technique before moving on to the next weight jump.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69657080
No problem bro, but typically the rep range is decided by the exercise, and what you want to get out of the exercise (If you're training for hypertrophy, you'll generally want to be in the 5-20 rep range, but it can go as high as 30 for some movements, notably certain rear delt exercises). You can use a very simple method; take a rep range (doesn't really matter), try it, and see if you get any problems with it, and with that information, you can adjust it further to better suit the exercise.
EG for me, doing wide grip deficit RDLs in the 15-20 rep range wouldn't work out very well due to being limited by cardio and the immense set duration due to the enormous ROM, so in this case I would lower the reps (in reality I do 5-10 reps on those).
As another example, if I did finger curls (an exercise with a very short ROM) in the 5-10 rep range, I probably wouldn't feel my forearms much and I would feel like I'm just fucking up my wrists, so I would take a higher rep range next time (in reality I do 15-20 reps on finger curls).
Generally the limiting factors will be: Tendon/Joint stress (take a higher rep range or fix your tendons/joints), Cardiovascular failure (take a lower rep range or improve your cardio), Excessive set duration (take a lower rep range), Synergist failure (eg forearms on db bench or lower back on squats, take a lower rep range), Mechanical failure (technique breaks down before muscular failure, this can be for reasons other than the rep range though. might want to adjust up or down depending on the conditions), Failure due to excessive pain from burn/pump before true muscular failure (take a lower rep range), Excessive systemic fatigue (generally happens on high axial load exercises like squats and deadlifts, take a higher rep range and modify the exercise to make it harder).
(1/2)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69657080
As for sets, the two factors are
>How much volume does the muscle need?
and
>Will this amount of sets produce an excessive amount of physical/mental fatigue that will interfere with the rest of the session/other sessions in the week?
For the first factor, if say you want more sets on chest because you can tolerate more volume and growing your chest is a priority, then you can choose to add more sets. Pretty self explanatory.
The second factor is a bit more complicated though. It depends on how physically and mentally fatigued you get by a given exercise. For example, maybe dips give you a great stimulus and don't produce a lot of systemic fatigue or mental fatigue, so you could do 5 sets and be completely fine. On the other hand, maybe squats produce a ton of systemic and mental fatigue (due to how hard they are), so 5 sets wouldn't be a good idea, 3 would be better instead. If this causes problems with factor 1 due to insufficient volume, you can use exercises that are less systemically and mentally fatiguing to fill in volume gaps.
For one example, maybe you really like squats and they aren't mentally fatiguing, but they still cause a lot of systemic fatigue that you cannot recover from if you do more sets. Instead, you can add in some bulgarian split squats to get the extra volume as they are less mentally fatiguing.
On the other hand, if say deadlifts are really mentally fatiguing but not too systemically fatiguing, you could take a variation of the deadlift that is still systemically fatiguing but less mentally fatiguing and do that for extra volume (Snatch grip deadlifts? Deficit deadlifts? Pause deadlifts? Rackpulls? Trap bar deadlifts? Not really sure as I'm not very big on deadlifts but you get the point.)

>>69657080
Also one last thing, the size of the range (eg 4x6-12 is a wider range than 4x8-10) depends on how much strength you lose on each given set of an exercise, and of course how many sets you do (eg if you're doing 6 sets you're going to need a pretty big range). For example if you lose a LOT of strength after each set of squats, you'll probably want a fairly wide range. But if say on bench press you only lose a little strength after each set, you can take a more narrow rep range for this reason. A third factor is what kind of weight jumps are you taking. If you're taking very large weight jumps, you'll want a very wide rep range so you don't fall out of it immediately after adding weight. For example, I do 4x8-16 on deficit strict barbell rows because I add 5kg when I reach 16 reps on the first set with good technique. If I did say 4x12-16 I would immediately fall out of the rep range as I would probably get 10, 9, 9, 8 on my first session with the new load, but with 4x8-16 I'm still within the range, so it works out.

Depends what muscles you're talking about. For example, weighted tailor's pose for reps can replace the adductor machine, super quad biased squat variations (think narrow stance, heel elevation, high-bar/front/ssb) can replace compound quad leg machines (leg press hack squat and others), nordic curls replace hamstring curl machines, etc.
For calves I do single leg calf raises, adding weight with a dip belt. Slow eccentric, hold the bottom position for 3 seconds (10 seconds after the last rep) while pulling yourself deeper with your tibialis anterior while keeping your knee straight. I typically do a ton of negatives on these, I use a weight that I can only get 2-4 full reps on but after those I do 10+ negatives. Insane DOMS if you haven't done them before. For the soleus I do single leg KOT calf raises (adding weight with a dip belt again), honestly I'd probably prefer a seated calf machine but these do the job just fine. I use a more typical tempo on these though.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69658405
>I want to take it to the next level but I don’t think I can do much more
Frequency, frequency, frequency. The back is a conglomerate of a lot of muscle groups of varying sizes, so trying to put them all in one session will result in one part getting trained really well and another part getting trained rather poorly depending on what the exercise ordering is. That and most of the upper-back muscles are very fatigue resistant anyway, so you could train them on back-to-back sessions and be just fine as long as you manage your recovery well. I personally train my upper back 4 times per week.

On upper days I do horizontal and vertical pulls, slightly biased toward horizontal pulls as I do 2 per session while only 1 for vertical pulls as well as some lower trap isolation (might move the lower trap isolation around though).
On lower days I do more upper back work, mostly lats (front lever pulls superset with bodyweight chinups, and straight arm pullovers), rear delts (powell raises) and infraspinatus/teres minor (db external rotations https://youtu.be/44wU6u8x3rw?t=323) as I can still do more lat volume and I don't isolate the rear delts/infraspinatus/teres minor on upper days. For the erectors it's more like 2x a week obviously as most of the volume will come from lower body days, however I do deficit strict barbell rows on my second upper day that takes place 2 days before and after both lower body days so this adds a tiny bit of extra volume. And on my first upper day I do chest supported rows with thoracic flexion and extension which trains my thoracic erectors (if you can do these, round your thoracic spine as hard as you can for 10 seconds after the last rep of the last set. you'll feel it a TON, more than most of the other back muscles actually). Hope this information helps as you should be able to apply it to your own training.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>69660598
its called double progression.
linear = only increase weight
double = increase reps/weight
triple = increase reps/weight/sets
generally i think linear only really works for beginners since they can progress so quickly, adding 5lbs per workout and shit. double is king imo but i increase sets if I think i can get another set within my planned rep range
effective rep ranges are generally between 5-30 reps for growing muscle, but id keep it between 6-20 since higher reps are psychologically harder to take close to failure, take longer, and are kinda boring imo.
Lower reps/Heavier weight is more reserved for the compound lifts, so with deadlifts you dont want to do 20 reps since it's so fatiguing, and with say rear delts you would want to do 20 reps since it's such a small muscle so it can't move much weight and thus needs more stimulus to grow. I think it's helpful to look at tonnage (amount of weight the muscle is moving) when you're deciding. Hamstrings are a good example. Deadlifts obviously work hamstrings pretty well, but people go really heavy and lower the reps on those because they move so much weight - whereas a Good Morning uses much less weight, so even though it still works the hammies, people increase the reps.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>69660992
Seated good mornings change the hip extension pattern from glutes and hamstrings to glutes and adductors, which is more specific to a squat, while also mimicking the hip flexion angle in the bottom of a squat much better than hamstring-dominant hinges such as standing good mornings and RDLs
>>69660598
>In general with this rep method, are you supposed to be increasing weights each time?
You increase in weight once you reach the top of the rep range on your first set with good technique (eg if you think that your technique needs a little work you can retake the weight again until it's good, then you can move on). EG on barbell bench 3x8-12 if I get 12, 11, 9 I would go up in weight if the technique is good enough.
>And what is the general volume of reps per muscle group if you’re just trying to grow muscle?
The volume would be measured in sets not reps, and it depends on the muscle and the individual, so you should find out for yourself by trying it out in the gym and modifying it based on how you recover (EG if you recover super fast, add more sets, if you take too long to recover before your next session, remove some sets). As a general rule for example, hamstrings cannot take much volume, while the lats and traps can take quite a lot of volume, but even then this will vary between individuals, so do your own testing.

posts.com:
>>69658518
To get it off of your security monitoring system you need to know what your security system is. If it is a remote camera then it should have some sort of memory card or a port to connect it. If it wired or wifi it would be connected to a computer that would have the recording. If that is the case then you need to look up your software that is on that computer that is connected to the cameras. You can find instructions online for how to use the software. There should be a file that it automatically saves to or you may have to use the software to make a permanent save. After you have the recording you can convert into a webm file if it is a short recording or upload the file to youtube. You may have to use some video editing software to shorten the video as it may just save the whole days recording depending on your monitoring software. Windows has a video editor already installed. You may have to move the file off of your security computer to a flash drive and edit and upload the video from another computer.
